day1_0.TEXT_TEXT: I can't believe I left her...

day1_1.TEXT_TEXT: The guards words echo in my head as I shift aimlessly in line.

day1_10.TEXT_TEXT: From the red faces and weak knees of people returning from the front of the line, it seems that correct answers aren't being given.

day1_12.TEXT_TEXT: I hadn't realized I was next up. The skinny blond boy in a crisp uniform looks far too young to be the one I'm talking to.

day1_13c.TEXT_TEXT: What's going on? When can I see my daughter?

day1_14a.TEXT_TEXT: Okay Will, what can I do for you.

day1_14b.TEXT_TEXT: Before I attempt to answer any question I am required to get your name.

day1_15a.TEXT_TEXT: I would be upset at his disregard for my name but the officer looked... off.

day1_15b.TEXT_TEXT: The officer somehow looks worse for wear than I do. His eyes dart nervously between me and everything else.

day1_16a.TEXT_TEXT: His eyes dart nervously between me, the other concerned people in line, and a stack of papers I can't read.

day1_16b.TEXT_TEXT: Ok Will, what questions do you have?

day1_17.TEXT_TEXT: The officer reaches for a clock on the booth and sets the timer to 60 seconds. My time is running out.

day1_18a.TEXT_TEXT: What is going on, why do we have to evacuate?

day1_18b.TEXT_TEXT: I put my daughter in evacuation site C last night. Is that safe? When can I go?

day1_18c.TEXT_TEXT: Are we the only town? Is the entire country in danger?

day1_19a.TEXT_TEXT: On behalf of the government, I can assure you that your safety is our utmost priority.

day1_19b.TEXT_TEXT: On behalf of the government, I can assure you that your safety is our utmost priority.

day1_19c.TEXT_TEXT: On behalf of the government, I can assure you that your safety is our utmost priority.

day1_2.TEXT_TEXT: [i] ... we're only taking the kids, sir ... [/i]

day1_20a.TEXT_TEXT: That said, the recent evacuation is simply a precautionary measure for a gas leak found near the center of town.

day1_20b.TEXT_TEXT: That said, evacuation is happening in stages to prevent panic and ensure good use of resources.

day1_20c.TEXT_TEXT: That said, the issue is a localized gasleak to this town specifically. There is no danger to this town or any others in the surrounding area.

day1_21a.TEXT_TEXT: The leak is not an immediate danger, which is why evacuation is happening in stages to keep an orderly flow of people and resources.

day1_21b.TEXT_TEXT: Evacuation zones A, B, C, and D have been set up at city exits to assist civilians in their exit.

day1_21c.TEXT_TEXT: If thats true then why can't we get communication from anywhere else?

day1_22a.TEXT_TEXT: If the leak isn't dangerous why evacuate in the first place?

day1_22b.TEXT_TEXT: Why do we need to go through evacuation zones? If the city exits were open we could all just leave.

day1_22c.TEXT_TEXT: Since last night the news has all been emergency broadcast and the phone lines aren't working.

day1_23a.TEXT_TEXT: This is just a precautionary measure. We expect everyone to return to town within a few months once the leak has been contained.

day1_23b.TEXT_TEXT: I assure you that would be far less optimal. This process assures we can report on the evacuation of each citizen.

day1_23c.TEXT_TEXT: There was an incident with the city row crew who first attempted to fix the gas leak that resulted in cut phone lines.

day1_24a.TEXT_TEXT: What part of [i]precaution[/i] involves separating families? If it's just a gas leak why do kids need to be evacuated first?

day1_24b.TEXT_TEXT: Why would you have to do that?

day1_24c.TEXT_TEXT: When the leak has been fixed, the phone lines will become our engineers' top priority.

day1_25a.TEXT_TEXT: I can assure you that this is all part of standard procedure for unkno- I mean, gas leak phenomena.

day1_25b.TEXT_TEXT: To ensure everyone that will sur- I mean, to get everyone who needs to be evacuated out of the town.

day1_25c.TEXT_TEXT: Are we just supposed to sit here and wait while you tell us what to do?

day1_26c.TEXT_TEXT: Precisely. It's the same for every other- ah, every other individual in this town.

day1_27.TEXT_TEXT: Listen Wilson, there's nothing to worry about. My report says the newest round of evacuation starts in five days.

day1_29.TEXT_TEXT: It will take five days for us to relocate everyone from evacuation zones A, B, C, and D to a secondary, secure location.

day1_3.TEXT_TEXT: I knew what to expect. They kept saying on the news there were only going to be so many evacuations in the first wave...

day1_30.TEXT_TEXT: What? Where are you moving them to??

day1_31.TEXT_TEXT: I am not at liberty to say, but I can assure you their safety is our top priority.

day1_32b.TEXT_TEXT: Where are you taking my daughter!?

day1_33.TEXT_TEXT: If I... I just can't tell you.

day1_33a.TEXT_TEXT: That's all I have to provide sir.

day1_33b.TEXT_TEXT: I'm not at liberty to say.

day1_34.TEXT_TEXT: If it weren't for the pistol at the mans hip his head would be in my hands.

day1_35.TEXT_TEXT: I have too many questions, too many things I need to scream at the officer. From the look on his face, I'm not the first today.

day1_39.TEXT_TEXT: He seems relieved as he says it. Can I really just leave now? Nothing makes sense, I can't let them take Molly without me.

day1_4.TEXT_TEXT: ... I just hoped I could change it.

day1_40a.TEXT_TEXT: You need to tell me more!

day1_41c.TEXT_TEXT: I lift my hands and back up.

day1_42.TEXT_TEXT: He nods as I walk away. For a moment before he collects himself to face the next angry person in line, he looks... genuinely sad...

day1_44.TEXT_TEXT: I don't have time to think about that though. I need to get home quick.

day1_45.TEXT_TEXT: Five days isn't much time, especially if I have to go on foot, but I can make it. I have to.

day1_46.TEXT_TEXT: Im going back to evacuation site C. I'm returning to Molly.

day1_48.TEXT_TEXT: The walk home was fast. Uniformed men wave me along as I pass. What are they looking for? Who are they protecting?

day1_49.TEXT_TEXT: It's hard to believe this much of a large-scale response could be caused by a small, non-threatening gas leak...

day1_5.TEXT_TEXT: Clearly I'm not the only one. The questioning booth was too far away to see by the time I got in line.

day1_50.TEXT_TEXT: For now I need to focus on supplies. Based on this [b]map[/b], it's a five day walk from my house to Molly's location.

day1_51.TEXT_TEXT: The first three days will be walking through the city. Shouldn't be that bad, I guess I just have to avoid any gas.

day1_52.TEXT_TEXT: The last two days will be involve going through the woods towards the northmost entrance to town.

day1_53.TEXT_TEXT: I'll need food, water, my map, and maybe a weapon. I can use the walkie talkie to talk to Molly... hopefully.

day1_54.TEXT_TEXT: Maybe I should take two. I can't forget stuffy either. I feel bad for hiding them in the first place.

day1_55.TEXT_TEXT: I'll get you back to her too stuffy.

day1_6.TEXT_TEXT: It all happened so fast. The news has been cryptic and the government has been silent.

day1_7.TEXT_TEXT: No one knows what or where the problem is. I've heard murmurs that its not just our city, but communication in and out of town is sparse.

day1_7b.TEXT_TEXT: Roads throughout town are being closed and blocked off. Soldiers in uniform seem to be posted at every intersection.

day1_8.TEXT_TEXT: All we know is we need to evacuate.

day1_9.TEXT_TEXT: The booth was announced late last night on the news, our first chance to get some real information.
